pr_title: Ignore lock node during orphan connector node cleanup

timeline.message:
Merge pull request #1 from linkedin/master

Pull latest
Ignore lock node during orphan connector node cleanup

timeline.bodyText: Did you mean to make it package private? That's less accessible than protected and would still allow you to access it in ZkAdapter.
timeline.author: ahmedahamid

timeline.bodyText: Should we also assert that one znode left is actually lock?
timeline.author: ahmedahamid

timeline.bodyText:
This part seems a little extraneous.
Should this test really assert that lock remains after releaseTask()? All it cares about is that lock survives cleanUpOrphanConnectorTasks(). On the other hand, if we change ZkAdapter in the future to have it delete lock if it's no longer needed, why should this test start failing then?
timeline.author: ahmedahamid

replies.bodyText: I feel this part is okay to have. If the behavior changes in the future, whoever is making the change will get alerted and get aware of this existing behavior ( which is not very obvious) and help in either fixing the test or their new behavior.
replies.author: vmaheshw

timeline.author: somandal

timeline.bodyText: I'm a bit confused, when we call releaseTask it should delete the lock node. Is that not happening? Or is this because the ZkAdapter used here is not real? Or is this validating the connector/lock is still existing, without looking at what's in it? If the last one, then we may want to verify that we have a node such as connector/lock/<task>?
timeline.author: somandal

replies.bodyText: the releaseTask deletes the connector/lock/. The node connector/lock will not get deleted.
replies.author: vmaheshw
